Authors: Rusmanto T., Waworuntu S.R., Nugraheny H.
Title: Lead-lag effects in stock returns: Evidence from indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Rusmanto, T., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Waworuntu, S.R., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia; Nugraheny, H., Faculty of Business, Bina Nusantara International University, Jakarta, 10270, Indonesia
Abstract: The main purpose of this research is to determine the existence of lead-lag effects in stock returns in the Indonesia Stock Exchange. Fifty-eight companies were taken as samples, selected through industrial classification and selection criteria of leader and follower stocks. The data is analysed using Vector Auto Regression method to extrapolate and investigate the existence of lead-lag effects in Indonesian capital market. This study finds that returns to stocks with relatively high market capitalizations lead returns to stocks with relatively low market capitalizations in Indonesian industry portfolios. However, out of ten industries, there are only six who contribute significant result. This research concludes that lead-lag effects do exist in certain industries and it may assist investors in managing the trading strategy. Indonesian capital market is not efficient since lead-lag effects is one of the phenomenon, which against the EMH.
Author Keywords: Cross-correlation; Indonesia Stock Exchange; Lead-lag effects; Stock Returns
References: Boudoukh, J., Richardson, M.P., Whitelaw, R.F., Tale of three schools: Insights of autocorrelations of short-horizon stock returns (1995) Review of Financial Studies, 7 (3), pp. 539-573; Conrad, J., Kaul, G., Time variation in expected returns (1988) The Journal of Business, 61 (4), pp. 409-425; Fama, E., Permanent and temporary components of stock prices (1988) Journal of Political Economy, 96 (2), pp. 246-273; Fama, E.F., Efficient capital market, II (1991) The Journal of Finance, 46 (5), pp. 1575-1617; Gultekin, M.N., Gultekin, N.B., Stock market seasonality: International evidence (1983) Journal of Financial Economics, 12 (4), pp. 469-481; Haque, T., Lead-lag effects in Australian industry portfolios (2010) The Journal of Finance, 18 (3), pp. 267-290; Hou, K., Industry information diffusion and the lead-lag effects in stock returns (2007) Review of Financial Studies, 20 (4), pp. 1113-1138; Lo, A., Mackinlay, A., When are contrarian profits due to stock market overreaction? (1990) Review of Financial Studies, 3 (2), pp. 175-205. , http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/rfs/3.2.175; Mech, T.S., Portfolio return autocorrelation (1993) Journal of Financial Economics, 34 (3), pp. 307-344; Shleifer, A., (2000) Inefficient Markets: An Introduction to Behavioural Finance, , Oxford: Oxford University Press
